title: 108_hr3574
content: The Act titled "Stock Option Accounting Reform Act" mandates the expensing of stock options held by highly compensated officers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require the expensing of stock options for named executive officers and the four most highly compensated executive officers of registered issuers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 now requires registered issuers to report the fair value of stock options granted to named executive officers in their annual reports. The fair value is determined by the agreement between willing buyers and sellers, considering all characteristics and restrictions of the option. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 mandates reporting the fair value of stock options granted to executives. The fair value is determined using option pricing models like Black-Scholes or binomial, with zero assumed volatility for the underlying stock. Exemptions apply to small business issuers meeting specific criteria. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires reporting the fair value of stock options granted to executives using option pricing models like Black-Scholes or binomial. Exemptions apply to small business issuers meeting specific criteria, including those with outstanding securities valued at less than $25,000,000 held by non-affiliated parties. The requirements do not apply to an issuer within 3 years of completing an initial public offering. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires reporting the fair value of stock options granted to executives using option pricing models. Small business issuers meeting specific criteria are exempt, including those with securities valued at less than $25,000,000 held by non-affiliated parties. Issuers may choose to expense the fair value of officer and employee stock options in their annual report. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON EXPENSING AND ECONOMIC IMPACT STUDY. Prohibition on expensing of stock options under the Securities Act of 1933, requiring compliance with specific requirements and completion of an economic impact study. When an option to purchase stock subject to section 13(m) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is exercised, any expense previously reported under section 13(m) for the option is recomputed as the difference between the stock price and exercise price. When an option to purchase stock subject to section 13(m) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is exercised, any expense previously reported for the option is adjusted based on the stock price and exercise price. If the option is forfeited or expires unexercised, the expense is not incurred. When an option to purchase stock subject to section 13(m) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is exercised, any reported expense is adjusted based on stock and exercise prices. If the option expires or is forfeited unexercised, the expense is not incurred. Any excess reduction in expenses is reported as income for options to purchase the issuer's stock. The Stock Option Accounting Reform Act allows the Commission to recognize the expensing alternative of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards Number 123 for issuers choosing to expense the fair value of all officer and employee stock options. A joint study on the economic impact of mandatory expensing of all employee stock options will be conducted by the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of Labor within one year of the Act's enactment. The impact of mandatory expensing of all employee stock options includes its effect on broad-based stock option plans for employee ownership, recruitment and retention of skilled workers, stimulation of research and innovation, economic growth in the United States, and the international competitiveness of U.S. businesses. Improved employee stock option transparency and reporting disclosures. The Commission will require issuers to provide enhanced disclosures on stock option plans and employee equity arrangements in periodic reports, including detailed information on dilutive effects and expanded disclosure on the impact of employee stock options on earnings per share. The Commission will require issuers to provide enhanced disclosures on stock option plans and employee equity arrangements in periodic reports, including details on dilutive effects, comparability, outstanding stock options, exercise prices, and estimated vesting. Definitions include the Commission as the SEC and issuer as defined in the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, with equity interest encompassing various securities. The Commission will require enhanced disclosures on stock option plans and employee equity arrangements, including details on dilutive effects, comparability, outstanding stock options, exercise prices, and estimated vesting. This encompasses phantom stock, securities replicating investment characteristics, and rights or options to acquire such securities. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF AUTHORITY. This Act does not limit the authority of any accounting standard setting body recognized by the Securities and Exchange Commission under section 19(b)(1) of the Securities Act of 1933.
